advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (AUG. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>U.K. prices:<br> Monochrome: <b>£299</b><br> Colour: <b>£399</b></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to <a href="http://blogs.linux.ie/fuzzbucket/archives/p/7/more/1/c/1/Vintage-Sinclair-QL-catalogue" target="_blank">fuzzbucket</a> for this complete QL catalogue.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, but nothing seems right in the picture...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Muffat</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMC INTERNATIONAL</strong></font><br><blockquote>It seems that the CMC Company (We have no more info about this company) used SuperBrain systems in which they added various hard disks, from 5 to 20 MB. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #5 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Our word processing system changed Isaac Asimov's mind about writing...<br> <b>"I may never use a typewriter again!"</b> Isaac likes the time he saves using SuperSCRIPSIT, our newest word processing program...<font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Canon AS-100. Programmed to succeed."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>cover</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #5 (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">If you could talk to Thomas Edison, he'd tell you what it was like to turn the light on in 1879. You could tell him about some bright idea of the 20th century... particularly, a technological phenomenon that can handle everything from solar heat control to lighting you home via voice command. The Apple personal computer...<br> ... With Apple, Edison could've written a program to determine why some filaments burned longer than others...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> What makes the QX-10 the most remarkably usable computer to date is a unique software system called VALDOC...<br><br> ... VALDOCS may be all the software you will never need. Right out of the box, it's a sophisticated <i>word processor</i>; an <i>information indexer</i> for easy acces to files; an <i>electronic mail system</i>;a <i>calculator</i>;an <i>apointment book</i> and <i>notepad</i>; and a <i>high resolution business graph drawing system</i>...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> POPULAR ELECTRONICS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover and extracts of a 6 page article in the January 1975 issue of Popular Electronics</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARABIC MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>In late 1988, bilingual (arab / french) versions of the TO-7/70 were sold for peanuts. These models could display latin and arabic characters. The keyboard was also bilingual, as well as the Basic !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1979 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert shows: <br><br> - the <b>WH89</b> computer ($2295)<br> - the <b>WH11A</b> 16-bit computer, DEC PDP 11/03 compatible ($1895)<br> - the <b>WH19</b> video terminal ($995)<br> - the <b>WH26</b> dual floppy disc system ($2595)<br> - the <b>WH14</b> serial printer ($895)<br><br> To note: in 1979, the company name was <b>Heath Schlumberger data systems.</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated december 1980</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DESKTOP & PORTABLE BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST SALES</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert (a bargain!) was published in the U.K. in September 1987</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #3 (1979) </strong></font><br><blockquote>From Playboy December 1979. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Peathead</b></p></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: power on/off, doubles/skeet/practice, serve manual/auto, TV channel 3/4 on the underside
computer.description:
APF TV Fun Model 401 is a classic pong system. It is one of the first system based on the common AY-3-8500 chipset from General Instruments. Thus, it offers four basic pong games : tennis, hockey, squash and single handball.
The case is quite nice with woodgrain style finish and silver-like knobs, switches and buttons... Switches are used to turn the system on and off, select game option and service mode (auto/manual). Buttons are used to reset the system and serve the ball. Game selection is made through a small dial in the middle of the control panel.
The controllers are built-in the case. These are two dials placed on both sides of the case. The RF cable is built into the unit, but it's possible to unplug it from the insides of the machine for replacement. The system can be powered by six C-size batteries or by an external power supply.
The TV Fun model 401 is not to be mistaken with later APF models which used the same case. There are TV Fun Model 401A and TV Fun Sportsarama.
computer.name: TV Fun (Model 401)
computer.power: External power supply unit, 9V 500 mA tip positive
